The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the global food demand will increase by 50% to meet the needs of the growing population. This will be challenging to achieve as the Earth’s climate continues to warm. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded. Here, we quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. Our results show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases to 86% under 4 °C warming. This will have severe consequences for global grain trade and international grain prices, especially for the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty. Our results underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This study is important for the global food security debate, especially in the context of climate change. It also has implications for the global trade of grains and other crops.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to design composite structures with multiple material phases to achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for biodiversity conservation in the United States. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring and adaptive management, and was the first to require a forest plan for a large area of federal land. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test the influence of this policy on biodiversity. Our results show that the NWFP halted the decline of early-seral–associated birds, but failed to reverse declines of older-forest–associated birds. The NWFP is a unique opportunity to evaluate the influence of policy. Our findings underscore the importance of continuing to prioritize older forests under the NWFP and ensuring that the recently proposed creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the control of lymphoproliferation, autoantibody production, and autoimmunity. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to trace the evolution of beetles and to estimate the timing and rates of beetle diversification. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]), which is a surrogate for probing the reactivity of the brain to DA stimulation. The reduced reactivity to methylphenidate is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, which are common symptoms of marijuana addiction. These findings highlight the importance of investigating the effects of chronic marijuana use on brain function.

Here, we show that the most powerful artificial neural networks for predictive text generation also predict brain responses to sentences in humans. This suggests that predictive processing may be a fundamental mechanism for how the human brain comprehends language. We also find that model architecture contributes to neural fit. These results provide computationally explicit evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning. However, it is still a black box, and it is not clear why it works. In this paper, we show that the success of DL is due to the existence of stable neural networks (NNs). We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable NNs, but there does not exist any algorithm that can train (or compute) such a NN. This is a fundamental result that explains the success of DL. It also provides a classification theory for the existence of algorithms that can train stable NNs. We introduce a new algorithm, fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENET), which we prove and numerically verify to be stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem. This is a major step toward understanding deep learning.

It shows that the experiment’s design flaws were overlooked at the time, and that they have led to a misunderstanding of the study’s results.

Leprosy is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Mycobacterium leprae. Although the disease is curable, it remains a major public health problem in the developing world. The causative agent of the noninfectious, chronic, and often fatal reactional state known as Lucio’s phenomenon, M. lepromatosis, has been identified only recently. This study provides the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis and reveals that it is more closely related to the leprosy bacillus than to any other known Mycobacterium. The ancient divergence of M. lepromatosis and M. leprae suggests that the two pathogens have retained many of the same functions for survival in the human host. Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the key ingredients for the emergence of classicality and the origin of the second law of thermodynamics. However, the interplay between them is still poorly understood. In this work, we provide a complete description of the entanglement dynamics in quantum quenches of the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain. We show that the entanglement dynamics is captured by a statistical ensemble with a nonzero thermodynamic entropy. This result is obtained by combining integrability with a quasiparticle picture of the entanglement dynamics. Our work provides a general framework for the study of the entanglement dynamics in quantum quenches. It also opens the way to the study of the entanglement dynamics in interacting systems.

Plague, caused by Yersinia pestis, is a zoonotic disease with a long history of outbreaks. The bacterium can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways, including the bite of infected fleas. In this study, we developed a compartmental model for plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We used Bayesian inference to fit mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe. Our results suggest that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by human ectoparasites during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This study provides a better understanding of the history of plague in Europe and may help to prevent future outbreaks. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The brain is the most complex and sophisticated organ in the animal kingdom. It is also the most expensive one, in terms of the number of cells it contains. The evolution of brain size has been extensively studied, but the evolution of brain neurons has been neglected. This study fills this gap by reconstructing the evolution of brain neurons across amniotes. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition. Our results also suggest that the evolution of brain size and neuronal density may be decoupled. This study provides a more complete picture of the evolution of brain size and its underlying mechanisms. It is therefore of great interest to the neuroscience community.

The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is broadly considered to be an anticancer target. However, the function of TRAP1 in mitochondria of normal cells is not well understood. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate cell motility. They are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. ADF/cofilin is a key regulator of cell motility, as it is required for the disassembly of actin filaments. However, how it does so is not fully understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever actin filaments in a mechanical context. We show that the mechanical state of the filament network can be used to control the severing rate of ADF/cofilin. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF/cofilin can efficiently sever actin filaments in cells. This is important for understanding how ADF/cofilin is used in cells to regulate cell motility. It is also important for understanding how ADF/cofilin is used in cells to regulate other processes, such as cytokinesis.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian ancestry for all Malagasy individuals. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry reveals that the settlement happened in a sex-biased and heterogeneously manner across Madagascar. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a comprehensive view of the genomic diversity of Madagascar, which is a unique case study for understanding the settlement history of the island. Emotional contagion is the phenomenon of people experiencing the same emotions as others without their awareness. This work shows that emotional contagion can occur in social networks, and that it can be positive. This work also suggests that in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people.

The ribosome is a complex molecular machine that reads messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences and translates them into a protein. The mRNA sequence is modified in many ways, and one of the most common modifications is the pseudouridine (Ψ) modification. Ψ is often found in mRNA coding regions, and we show that the presence of Ψ can modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. Our work suggests that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA coding regions and that this can have consequences for translation. Our findings have implications for understanding mRNA modification and translation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including stronger social relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone. These associations are robust to adjustment for a range of factors that may also predict these outcomes, such as socioeconomic status, depressive symptoms, and wealth. Longitudinal analyses indicate that higher worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes over a 4-y period. The feeling that one’s life is worthwhile may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study provides evidence for the importance of a sense of worthwhile living in the lives of older people. (PsycINFO Database Record

The evolution of body size is a central topic in biology. The aquatic mammals are a unique group of animals that have colonized the water and diversified. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and examination of the fossil record to test the hypothesis that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. We find that the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in all four extant aquatic mammal lineages. The aquatic lifestyle is also driving the evolution of a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This size attractor is consistent with energetic constraints on the evolution of body size in the aquatic realm. The aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes, but the aquatic lifestyle is not releasing aquatic mammals from size constraints. Rather, the aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes, and the aquatic lifestyle is also confining aquatic mammals to a relatively narrow range of body sizes.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. The virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. The mechanism of temperature-dependent growth is not known. We show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This correlates with higher expression levels of type I and type III IFN genes and ISGs at 37 °C. Temperature-dependent IFN induction in response to rhinovirus is dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of mouse airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C leads to greater IFN induction at 37 °C relative to 33 °C at early time points poststimulation and to a sustained increase in the induction of ISGs at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. The opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in cystic fibrosis patients. It is able to cause severe lung damage by producing a variety of virulence factors, including toxins, proteases, and biofilm-inducing enzymes. The mechanisms that allow this bacterium to cause disease are not fully understood. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses its type IV pili to sense the mechanical activity of these appendages, which in turn regulate the expression of genes involved in surface attachment and virulence. This is a unique mechanism that allows bacteria to sense the mechanical activity of their own surface appendages and is likely to be used by other bacteria as well. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms that allow bacteria to cause disease. It also provides a new target for the development of new antibiotics.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the consequences of this development for the quality of surface water are not well understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions. This study is of high relevance for the global community and for the scientific community working on the consequences of agricultural pesticide use.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society. The persistence of SARS-CoV-2 in animal reservoirs is a major concern for the long-term sustainability of the pandemic. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer. We also show that the virus can be transmitted between deer. These findings have important implications for the future of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a low-carbon energy future. This is a good thing. However, the world is still heavily reliant on fossil fuels and nuclear energy. The best way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions is to increase the use of renewable energy sources. Hydropower is the leading renewable energy source. However, the world is still building large dams in the developing world. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable energy sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder characterized by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau proteins. The exact mechanisms by which these proteins contribute to the disease are not fully understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ and oligomers are toxic to neurons, and that they are responsible for the release of inflammatory factors from neurons. We also show that the release of these factors is dependent on the presence of microglia. These findings suggest that the accumulation of Aβ in the brain may be a key factor in the initiation of the AD-related inflammatory response. This study provides a better understanding of the role of the immune system in AD pathogenesis. It also provides a potential target for the development of new therapeutic strategies. The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still debated. We present a comprehensive survey of the chicken bone assemblage from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia. Our results show a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We argue that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the chicken and its role in the development of the agricultural economy. It also sheds light on the role of the Hellenistic period in the spread of domesticated species across the Mediterranean. (PsycINFO Database Record

The folding of proteins is a major unsolved problem in biology. The kinetic folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, was studied by advanced hydrogen-exchange mass spectrometry. The results show that the folding of maltose binding protein is a multistep process. The folding intermediates are distinct and are not the same as the denatured state. The results also show that the folding intermediates are not the same as the native state. The results are consistent with the hypothesis that the folding of proteins is a multistep process. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is mediated by the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH. This enzyme recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to better understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a fascinating phenomenon in nature and in physics. It is characterized by the fact that the system is in a critical state, but the rate of change of the system is not constant. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with SOC behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for optoelectronics, quantum computing, and other applications. However, its properties are difficult to control and tune. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly in a wide range of strain. This opens up opportunities to control the bandgap of diamond, which is a key property for many applications. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, which is important for applications that require diamond to be graphite. Our findings can be used to control the properties of diamond for a wide range of applications.

The role of plant immune peptides in defense against fungal pathogens is well established. However, the structural basis for antifungal activity of plant immune peptides is not well understood. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from the legume Medicago truncatula. This peptide is highly dynamic and has a unique structure with one α-helix and one β-sheet. The antifungal activity of this peptide is due to its ability to bind to multiple bioactive phosphoinositides in germlings of the fungal pathogen Botrytis cinerea. The antifungal activity of this peptide is also due to its ability to penetrate the fungal cell wall and cell membrane at discrete foci, followed by gradual loss of turgor, subsequent accumulation in the cytoplasm, and elevated levels in nucleoli of germlings. This work provides a structural basis for antifungal activity of plant immune peptides and opens up the possibility of developing this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. We also show that female-derived proteins are enriched in the sperm proteome after mating and that these proteins support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, promoting blood clotting. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). The A1 domain in VWF binds to platelet glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα), but the mechanism of this interaction is not understood. We show that force application switches VWF A1 and GPIbα to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWD. The mechanism is also relevant to other proteins that bind to receptors on the cell surface. This article is protected by copyright. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of microbes that has been shown to influence human health. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that associate with humans, has been difficult to study. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, including 45,000+ unique virus taxa. We also show that large case-control studies can be reanalyzed to identify virus–disease associations. This resource will enable future studies of the human virome and its impact on human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is because of the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-FOV high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties. The observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for decades. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence is ∼15 °C, whereas the temperature inferred from protein evidence is ∼70 °C. Here, we show that the temperature inferred from protein evidence is consistent with that inferred from the thermostability of ancestral enzymes. This finding is significant because the thermostability of ancestral enzymes is a robust and independent method of reconstructing ancient temperatures. The results presented here provide a new method for reconstructing the temperature of Earth’s surface over geological time. This method may be applied to other proteins to further refine our understanding of the evolution of life on Earth.

Ion channels are the molecular switches that control ion flow. The activation gate is the molecular switch that opens the channel pore and allows ions to flow through. The inactivation gate is the molecular switch that closes the channel pore and stops ions from flowing. The activation gate is commonly located at the intracellular end of the channel pore, whereas the inactivation gate is commonly located at the selectivity filter. However, the activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We found that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. These findings provide insights into the molecular mechanism of K+ channel activation/deactivation and C-inactivation/recovery. They also provide a foundation for the development of K+ channel modulators. This article is protected by copyright.

Malaria is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The parasite exploits a number of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC). However, the role of these pathways in the invasion process has not been fully elucidated. Here, we show that the erythrocyte-binding antigen EBA175 alters the biophysical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that invasion is a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces. This study provides a new perspective on the invasion process and opens up the possibility of developing new strategies to combat this devastating disease. This article is protected by copyright. Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In the temperate regions, seasonal influenza outbreaks correlate closely with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes mice more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that inhalation of dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. The brain is thought to build syntactic structures by merging words into phrases. However, whether and how the brain does so remains largely unknown. Here, we used intracranial recordings to investigate how brain activity varies with each successive word in a sentence. We found that high-gamma power increased with each successive word but decreased suddenly whenever words could be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity was consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This may be a fundamental property of the language system that is shared by humans and other animals. The merge operation may be a key step in the construction of syntactic structures.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. Axin is a key component of the pathway that converts signals at the plasma membrane to signals inhibiting the degradation of β-catenin, leading to its accumulation and specific gene activation. In vertebrates, there are two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes vigorous eating in sated animals. This effect is blocked by dopamine antagonists, and dopamine lesions or receptor antagonists reduce the effect. We show that this effect is mediated by a circuit involving LH neurons, ventral tegmental area (VTA) dopamine neurons, and neurons in the peri-locus coeruleus region of the LH. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to engineer nitrogen fixation in plants is a key component of sustainable agriculture. Here, we have developed a system for the control of nitrogen fixation in a cereal plant, using a synthetic signaling circuit between the plant and the nitrogen-fixing bacterium. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of principle for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signaling molecule. The engineered symbiosis is effective in the field, and the system is amenable to further improvements. This work is expected to have a significant impact on the field of synthetic biology and on the development of sustainable agriculture. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, and its deforestation is a major driver of climate change. Despite substantial investments in remote-sensed forest monitoring, deforestation alerts are rarely detected by the communities most directly affected by deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced deforestation in the communities that participated. However, the estimated effects are imprecise because of the program’s small sample size. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals are able to hear the world around them, but how this ability is achieved is still a mystery. We show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can hear the world around it by outsourcing its hearing to its web. The spider’s web acts as an acoustic antenna, which is able to detect the motion of the air particles caused by an incoming sound wave. The spider can then localize the source of the sound wave. This is a unique example of outsourcing hearing to an external medium, which provides a new paradigm for studying the sensing and manipulation of acoustic flow. The spider also provides a unique model for studying the evolution of hearing in animals. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The ALK family of receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) is implicated in a variety of human cancers. In the zebrafish, the DrALK/DrLtk signaling pathway controls the development of iridophores, pigment cells of neural crest origin. Here, we show that zebrafish DrALK/DrLtk is activated by the three DrALK/DrALKALS. We further show that loss of DrALK/DrALKALS causes iridophore loss, whereas overexpression of the DrALKALS causes ectopic iridophore development. Our findings may help to understand the role of ALK/LTK family RTKs in human cancer. They may also provide a basis for the development of new zebrafish-based approaches for the identification of new therapeutic targets and the development of zebrafish-based models for neural crest-related diseases. The emergence of plague as a human pathogen is one of the most dramatic events in human history. The study of ancient plague genomes has revealed the pathogen’s early evolution and ecology, but the number of genomes available to date has been too small to explore its diversity during the critical period of its development. Here, we present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Eurasian Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age (LNBA) period, which spans 5,000 to 2,500 y BP. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents. These data provide insights into the pathogen’s early evolution and ecology, which may have been shaped by its adaptation to fleas. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the relationship between men’s and women’s endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) and their support for Donald Trump. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical issue for the global food system and climate change. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to massive losses of SOC. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems to mitigate these losses remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that incorporate perennial pastures and livestock can increase SOC storage and the amount of SOC stored in the mineral soil. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to mitigate climate change and support the global food system. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We used expert opinion and scientific evidence to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans. We then developed a risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, that estimates a risk score for wildlife-origin viruses, creating a comparative risk assessment of viruses with uncharacterized zoonotic spillover potential alongside those already known to be zoonotic. We validated the risk assessment using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The top 12 ranked viruses were known zoonotic viruses, including SARS-CoV-2. Several newly detected viruses ranked higher than known zoonotic viruses. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is a key trait that attracts pollinators. The genetic history of Europe is a complex story of migrations and invasions. However, the genetic history of the population during the period of cultural change is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 450 and 750 AD. Our results indicate that the genetic ancestry of the population is very heterogeneous, including signals of genetic ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides insights into the genetic history of Europe during the period of cultural change. It also demonstrates the potential of the use of genome-wide data to study the genetic history of Europe.

The lagging strand of DNA replication is synthesized by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the sliding clamp proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). The origin of life is a central problem in biology. The RNA world is a hypothesized stage in the evolution of life, in which genetic information was encoded by RNA molecules and replicated by ribozymes. In this paper, we describe the evolution of a ribozyme that can replicate RNA molecules. This improved polymerase can synthesize a variety of RNA molecules, including aptamers, ribozymes, and tRNA. Furthermore, the polymerase can amplify RNA templates by more than 10,000-fold in an RNA-catalyzed form of PCR. Thus, the two prerequisites of Darwinian life—the replication of genetic information and its conversion into functional molecules—can now be accomplished with RNA in the complete absence of proteins. This work provides a foundation for the study of the origin of life. It also has implications for the design of synthetic life.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Frost is a major environmental stressor of plants and animals across the world’s temperate and boreal zones. The geographic distribution and evolutionary impact of frost events are poorly understood. We show that the resistance strategies of trees to late-spring frosts are region-specific and that these strategies are changing in response to the ongoing changes in frost frequencies. Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this observation is unclear. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different genetic causes, environmental factors, and clinical phenotypes. The disease is also progressive, with motor neuron degeneration occurring in the spinal cord, brainstem, and peripheral nerves. The disease is fatal within 3 to 5 y of onset. There is an urgent need to develop disease models and identify disease mechanisms and therapeutics. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living ALS patients. This will enable high-throughput screening of therapeutics to alleviate motor neuron degeneration. This will also enable disease modeling and identification of disease mechanisms and therapeutics. This will greatly accelerate the development of ALS therapeutics. This will also greatly improve the quality of life of ALS patients.

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the ability of the tick to transmit infectious agents to humans. We now demonstrate that the tick-borne pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum modifies the tick microbiota to enhance its transmission. We show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the gut microbiota. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the climate feedbacks. In this paper, we show that there is a feedback in the stratosphere that increases water vapor in the stratosphere with increasing tropospheric temperature. This feedback is significant, and it is the largest feedback in the stratosphere.

The Bible is one of the most widely read books in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of this parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. We report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals; however, we did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in some regions and decrease it in others. However, the relative importance of climate and human factors is poorly understood. We quantify the effects of climate and human factors on global fire activity and their impact on global warming. We find that human demography tends to suppress global fire activity, keeping more carbon within terrestrial ecosystems and attenuating warming. However, recent and predicted future reductions in fire activity may enhance land carbon uptake and corresponding to offsetting ∼5 to 10 y of global CO2 emissions at today’s levels. This potentially reduces warming by up to 0.11 °C by 2100. We show that ignitions and active and passive fire suppression can be as important in driving future fire regimes as changes in climate. Our study highlights the importance of fire in the global carbon cycle and the need to better understand the effects of climate and human factors on fire regimes. This is critical to understand the full range of future climate change scenarios.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved remain poorly understood. Text data are ubiquitous, but it is difficult to identify patterns in them. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We first identify a set of vectors that provide a sparse representation of an embedding space. We then infer the topic that generated a sequence of words. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model patterns in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of Yersinia pestis in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for four centuries. This period is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of the bacterium, after which the disease established itself in European rodents. However, we show that the climate conditions in Asia, where the disease originated, were favorable for reintroductions of the bacterium into Europe. Our results suggest that the disease was not permanently established in Europe, but was reintroduced into Europe on a regular basis.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web, and their loss would have a significant impact on the ecosystem. We report on a disease outbreak of asteroids that has recently occurred along the Pacific coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid mortality, and the cause is unknown. We show that the disease is caused by a virus, and we provide evidence that the virus is transmitted by a common sea star species. This study provides a clear link between a disease and a specific agent, and it provides a possible explanation for the recent asteroid mass mortality.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to accomplish this through the maintenance of elevated neural activity. However, this view does not explain how information is stored and retrieved. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. The etiology of autism is so complicated because it involves the effects of variants of several hundred risk genes along with the contribution of environmental factors. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the converging functions of autism-risk genes and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic approaches for autism. The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus metabolic targeting is a promising strategy for cancer therapy. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a promising metabolic target, as it is up-regulated in cancer, and its activity is required for cancer cell growth. We have developed a series of small-molecule inhibitors of SHMT, and have shown that they are effective in vitro and in vivo. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous neurodegenerative disease with a high degree of genetic heterogeneity. The disease is associated with the formation of intracellular inclusion bodies that contain a variety of proteins. These inclusions are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in ALS are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a unifying explanation for the neuropathological heterogeneity of ALS. It also provides a rationale for the development of therapeutic strategies that target the metastable proteins that are characteristic of the disease. (Read more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The earliest known angiosperms are poorly known. The research presented here centers on Montsechia vidalii, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. This plant has been poorly understood and misinterpreted in the past. Now, based upon the study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens, a detailed analysis of Montsechia is presented. The morphology and anatomy of the plant, including aspects of its reproduction, suggest that Montsechia is sister to Ceratophyllum (whenever cladistic analyses are made with or without a backbone). Montsechia was an aquatic angiosperm living and reproducing below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum. Montsechia is Barremian in age, raising questions about the very early divergence of the Ceratophyllum clade compared with its position as sister to eudicots in many cladistic analyses. Lower Cretaceous aquatic angiosperms, such as Archaefructus and Montsechia, open the possibility that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped DNA viruses that are ubiquitous in nature. They are associated with a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The evolution of parvoviruses has been estimated to be faster than that of RNA viruses, and it has been suggested that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus B19 (B19V) sequences from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Read more)

Sea level is a sensitive indicator of global climate change. In this study, we use a 25-y time series of satellite altimeter data to estimate the climate-change–driven acceleration of global mean sea level. We find that the acceleration is statistically significant and is consistent with the acceleration reported by the IPCC AR5. We also find that the rate of sea level rise is increasing, which is consistent with the findings of the IPCC AR5.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age in America today, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950 than for those born before 1950. This pattern is seen across measures of pain, including self-report, medical records, and mortality. It is also seen across measures of the burden of pain, including lost productivity and healthcare costs. The erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950 is reflected in the erosion of the working-class burden of pain.

The study of enzyme catalysis has been revolutionized by the development of NMR-assisted crystallography. This technique provides a means to characterize the chemical dynamics of enzyme active sites, including the location and orientation of hydrogen atoms, as well as the tautomeric states of functional groups. Here, we use this approach to characterize the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes that catalyze β-elimination and replacement reactions. The results provide a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of this intermediate, including the location of the water molecule that serves as a hydrogen bond donor to the ε-amino group of the catalytic βLys87 residue. The results also provide a mechanistic explanation for why indole, an isostere of the natural substrate, does not react, while the natural substrate does. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. (Read more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe pneumonia caused by a zoonotic coronavirus. There is no specific antiviral treatment for MERS. Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a broad-spectrum inhibitor of viral RNA synthesis, which has shown efficacy in the treatment of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS)-CoV. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection provides a clear clinical benefit, with a reduction in clinical signs, reduced virus replication in the lungs, and decreased presence and severity of lung lesions. The data presented here support testing of the efficacy of remdesivir treatment in the context of a MERS clinical trial. The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacterium, Vibrio fischeri, in a diel rhythm. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts, which is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is provided just before dusk, when the squid is preparing to produce light. We propose that this strategy may be used by other hosts to regulate the activities of their associated microbes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that a scalable, teacher-led intervention can reduce suspension rates by half. The intervention is simple: teachers are trained to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. This intervention is scalable because it can be implemented by teachers themselves, with minimal training. It is also sustainable because it can be maintained by teachers themselves. The intervention is also effective: it bolstered the respect students had for their teachers, and reduced suspensions among the most at-risk students.

However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe pneumonia, and the virus is a major threat to human health. The food system is a major contributor to global environmental change and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the global population are a key driver of this problem. In this study, we show that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a large university cafeteria increased the proportion of diners choosing vegetarian meals by 40% and had no detectable rebound effect. These results suggest that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering outlets could have a significant impact on the environment and population health. Our findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote sustainable diets. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for engaging the extracellular space in normal and cancer cells. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a panel of breast epithelial cells stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. In the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. This paper provides a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

This dimerization interface is unique to SARS-CoV-2 and may mediate unique immune suppression and evasion activities. These findings provide insight into the molecular basis of the severity of the COVID-19 disease. This work also provides a foundation for the development of therapeutics and vaccines. The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. This is a powerful idea, but it is not without its problems. One of these is the problem of selective inference. This is the idea that we must set a higher bar for declaring significant the associations that we see in a large dataset. This is a problem that is becoming more important in the era of big data. We describe some recent new developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are oncogenes in human cancers. Recently, we discovered two physiological ligands for Alk and Ltk, which we named augmentor-α and augmentor-β (FAM150A and FAM150B). These findings establish a physiological link between Alk and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentors are ligands for Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells. This study provides insights into the physiological function of Alk and Ltk and their ligands. It also provides a model system for studying the function of Alk and Ltk in vivo. β-cell dysfunction is a major molecular basis for type 2 diabetes (T2D). Although the role of STING in β-cell function has been reported, its function in the regulation of insulin sensitivity is still unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells and peripheral tissues caused glucose intolerance, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Moreover, we found that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, STING deficiency down-regulated Pax6 expression, which is required for GSIS. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. The genome of influenza A viruses is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our experiments indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms of viral genome packaging and the selective packaging mechanism. This knowledge is essential for the development of vaccines and antiviral drugs. (Read more)

Atherosclerotic lesions are characterized by the presence of a proinflammatory and proproliferative phenotype of endothelial cells (ECs). The underlying molecular mechanism of the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes of ECs is largely unknown. In this study, we found that the activation of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) is a critical step in the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes of ECs. In addition, statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibited the activation of YAP/TAZ, suggesting that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the disturbed flow-induced atheroprone phenotypes of ECs and a potential therapeutic target for the prevention of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States. This has led to increased economic and ecological costs of wildfire. We show that human activities have greatly expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. We also show that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in areas with higher fuel moisture, thereby helping to expand the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Our results highlight the importance of human activities in increasing the fire niche in the United States. Actions to reduce fire risk from human-caused wildfires should be a focus of United States policy.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Natural repellents are a sustainable and ecofriendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of these repellents in arthropod pests remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropod pests, which should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the immune response in the pathogenesis of ZIKV is still unclear. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques can be characterized. We also show that the antiviral treatment favipiravir can reduce the time to undetectable plasma viral load from ∼5 d to ∼3 d. Finally, we show that favipiravir given prophylactically starting at the time of infection can reduce the peak median plasma viral load by ∼3 logs and shorten the time to undetectable median plasma viral load by ∼2 d. Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse and valuable ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In particular, the breakdown of the symbiotic relationship between corals and their algal partners is considered to be the most severe threat to coral reefs worldwide. We show that the metabolic interactions between coral and symbionts are a key factor in the breakdown of the symbiosis. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to conserve this valuable ecosystem.

The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that protects the organism from the environment and regulates nutrient absorption and immune responses. In the absence of tumor suppression, intestinal tumors can lead to dysregulated host–microbe interactions and compromise host homeostasis. Here, we show that intestinal tumors can trigger a regenerative response in the microbiome, which in turn can promote tumor growth. We also show that inhibiting JNK signaling or depleting the microbiome can restore intestinal barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of how intestinal tumors can compromise host–microbe interactions and compromise host homeostasis. This work may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies to treat intestinal tumors and restore host–microbe homeostasis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinaselike orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 promotes the growth of breast cancer cells in vitro and in vivo. Finally, we show that the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can inhibit the growth of breast cancer patient-derived xenografts in mice. The start of accelerated deglaciation at the end of the last glacial period is commonly attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this explanation is not supported by paleoclimate records. These changes are consistent with a strong impact on Southern Hemisphere climate, including a shift in the location of the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. The Takahe eruptions plausibly link the start of accelerated deglaciation to the end of the last ice age. This study provides a unique example of how volcanic eruptions can impact climate and is a reminder that volcanic eruptions can have important impacts on our planet. Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and income for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our data can be used to inform environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity.

The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. However, the molecular mechanisms that control this capacity are poorly understood. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. Finally, we show that this DLK-independent regeneration is a form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth. Taken together, our study provides a unique platform for understanding the molecular control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.
