Recombination is a fundamental process in the generation of genetic diversity. It is also a highly variable process, with hotspots of intense activity interspersed among cold regions. The distribution of recombination rates in a genome can be used to infer the history of its evolution. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination rates in the genome of a flowering plant, Mimulus guttatus. We find that recombination rates are highly variable, with some regions of the genome exhibiting rates of 100,000 recombination events per centimorgan per generation, whereas other regions exhibit rates of 0.001 recombination events per centimorgan per generation. These results are similar to those observed in yeast and in mice. The distribution of recombination rates in plants may reflect ancient and conserved eukaryotic mechanisms. This work provides a detailed view of the recombination landscape in a flowering plant. It may also be useful in the study of recombination in other organisms.

The resting brain is a complex network of functionally connected regions. The identification of resting state networks (RSNs) is a major challenge in neuroscience. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography (PET) to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant RSN was topographically similar to the DMN in healthy subjects. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. PD patients showed reduced network expression, which was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In contrast, in Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. Metabolic imaging can directly provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease. This study provides a new perspective on the organization of the brain and its functional significance. It also provides a new approach to the study of brain disorders.

RNA modifications are important for the function of many RNAs in the cell. The recent discovery of 5′ nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) RNA in bacteria has raised the possibility that this modification is widespread in the cell. We show that 5′ NAD-RNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. This is the first report of a 5′ NAD+ cap in eukaryotes. The 5′ NAD+ cap may be important for the function of specific subsets of mRNAs.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. The molecular mechanisms underlying metabolic memory are not fully understood. We hypothesized that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells are associated with metabolic memory. We found that DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells are associated with glycemia for several years during the EDIC Study. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. Future studies are needed to confirm these findings in larger cohorts. This study provides a molecular basis for the metabolic memory observed in people with diabetes. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of TNBC tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of TNBC has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a complex disorder with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that some alcohol-dependent subjects have altered gut permeability, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol dependence. These results suggest that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The tomato is a model system for the study of fruit ripening, and the production of volatile chemicals is a major contributor to the fruit aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the only known nitrogenous volatiles are derived from cysteine. Here we report the discovery of a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes the biosynthesis of all the known nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This pathway is unique among the known nitrogenous volatiles, and the discovery of this pathway will enable the development of new strategies for the improvement of tomato flavor. Biodiversity loss and environmental warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that changes in temperature systematically alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. As temperatures depart from ambient conditions, the exponent of the diversity-functioning relationship increases, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This key result was driven by two processes linked to variability in the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the design of conservation and restoration strategies. They also highlight the need to consider the potential for synergistic effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for navigation. It encodes the spatial layout of the environment, including the location of the animal’s home and the direction of travel. The organization of MEC is not well understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells, which encode the animal’s position, are anatomically distinct from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. This suggests that grid cells may form a distinct network. Our results also suggest that the organization of MEC is more complex than previously thought. This study provides a powerful method for studying the organization of the MEC. It will be useful for understanding the function of this important brain region.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and developmental signals. In this study, we show that the FT gene in the rootless parasitic plant Cuscuta australis does not function in flowering induction. Instead, we demonstrate that the FT protein is able to move from the host to the parasite, where it physically interacts with a dodder FD transcription factor to activate dodder flowering. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The disease is associated with a loss of dopamine-containing neurons and a reduction in dopamine release in the striatum, the brain region that receives dopamine from the substantia nigra. The dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra are connected to the striatum by two major pathways: the nigro–striatal pathway, which is the focus of this study, and the nigro–thalamo–striatal pathway. The latter pathway is thought to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. We show that the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra are connected to the striatum by a third pathway, the striosome–dendron bouquet pathway. This pathway is likely to be involved in the control of mood and motivation. The striosome–dendron bouquet pathway may also be involved in the control of movement. This pathway is likely to be affected in Parkinson’s disease. Understanding the function of this pathway may help to explain the disease and to develop new treatments. We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked people to talk with each other and rated the felt connection. We found that the speed of response was a robust predictor of felt connection. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells (SANCs) are responsible for generating the heart rate. SAN automaticity is governed by a complex interplay between the membrane and Ca2+ clocks. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. Our study reveals a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of Ca2+ dynamics in SANCs. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern SAN function. These findings may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of heart failure. (PsycINFO Database Record

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. Although the function of Si in plant physiology has been well documented, its beneficial effects on plant resistance against insect herbivory have been less studied. In this study, we found that Si pretreatment increased rice resistance against the rice leaffolder in wild-type plants but not in RNAi lines that were silenced for jasmonate (JA) biosynthesis and perception genes. This interaction between Si and JA in defense against insect herbivores was associated with priming of JA-mediated defense responses and promotion of Si accumulation by JA. These results suggest that Si may be used as a biocontrol agent to enhance plant resistance against insect herbivory. This study also provides a mechanism for the use of Si as a biofertilizer. The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase are important regulators of the lipidome in murine macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism. They also suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome. This may have implications for the treatment of phenylketonuria.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to accomplish this through the maintenance of elevated neural activity. However, this view does not explain how information is stored and retrieved. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order and can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge for the development of RNA-based therapeutics. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNA to plants using DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructure are the key design parameters for the delivery of siRNA to plants. We also show that the endogenous gene silencing pathway depends on the attachment location of the siRNA. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work will be of interest to the plant biology and synthetic biology communities. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient sources from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused on large watersheds, leaving small tributaries largely unmonitored. We used a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan to determine how land cover and dams alter nutrient inputs across watershed sizes. We found that small watersheds are a significant source of coastal nutrient inputs, especially dissolved inorganic nutrients. Our findings suggest that nutrient management efforts should be expanded to address smaller watersheds, as they may play a disproportionate role in fueling algal blooms in nearshore areas. This could have important implications for the management of valuable nearshore ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the rare combinations of cosmological parameters are required to produce a universe with a small cosmological constant and a small fine-structure constant. We argue that the same mechanism may be at work in both contexts.

The mechanisms by which NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Abs change the intrinsic microcircuitry of the cortex, which in turn alters the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. We also show that the same parameter fluctuations in the microcircuitry can be tolerated in a model of the control condition, but that these fluctuations are critical for the development of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities when the microcircuitry is changed by NMDAR-Abs. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. They also suggest that the same mechanism may be responsible for the diverse range of EEG abnormalities observed in patients with NMDAR-Abs. This may help explain why treatment with immunosuppressants is often required to control the disease. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event. To understand the potential for future abrupt climate change, it is important to understand the history of abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a study of an abrupt warming event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was linked to a global-scale warming and anoxia of the ocean. The event was also linked to a doubling of atmospheric CO2. This study provides insights into the potential for future abrupt climate change.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia from 2001 to 2015. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for the palm oil industry. Rather, it is a tool that can be used to help achieve sustainable production of palm oil.

The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis, which is essential to organisms across kingdoms. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. Investigation of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the lethality or the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. Sex determination is a fundamental aspect of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination has been a major focus of evolutionary biology for decades. In vertebrates, sex determination is often a single locus, which results in two sexes. However, in many species, sex determination is polygenic, with multiple alleles segregating within a single species. Here we investigate the effects of polygenic sex determination in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles, one of which determines female sex, and one of which determines male sex, interact to produce four possible sex classes. We find that polygenic sex determination can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, and that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics can be increased by the acquisition of a new sex determination allele. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species- and light-induced photoproducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand how the levels of intracellular iron (Fe) impact the retina. We found that Fe levels in retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells, which are also challenged by accumulations of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoid lipofuscin) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species, were reduced in mice treated with the Fe chelator deferiprone. This finding suggests that Fe levels may be a critical factor in the oxidation and degradation of the bisretinoid A2E. These results provide insight into the mechanisms by which Fe levels may impact the retina and may be relevant to the pathogenesis of age-related macular degeneration. Predators are the main drivers of ecosystems, and the study of predator specialization is fundamental to understanding how food webs function. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as predators are constrained by the need to evolve morphological and functional optimizations throughout the organism. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not a dead end, but rather a stepping stone to morphological and functional diversification. Our findings help to understand how specialization has shaped present-day food webs.

The human hand is a complex structure with a variety of derived features that are shared with the living human and Neandertal populations and that are absent in early hominins. These features are thought to have played a role in the evolution of the human ability to use tools. The origin of these features is poorly understood, however, because of a lack of fossils from the time of their evolution. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from 1.42 My old that shows the third metacarpal styloid process, a key derived feature of the human hand, and thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this key shared derived characteristic of modern humans and Neandertals. This finding suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This study also highlights the importance of the fossil record in understanding the evolution of the human hand. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of both human cytosolic and mitochondrial serine hydroxymethyltransferse (SHMT). This inhibitor is effective in blocking colon cancer tumor xenograft formation. We have also identified a unique metabolic vulnerability of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer type that is notoriously difficult to treat. Our findings suggest that targeting SHMT may be a promising strategy for treating cancer.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not widely recognized. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which are important sources of vitamin A. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables, which is associated with higher vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets as well as their conservation and environmental benefits.

Modern agriculture is a major contributor to global food production, but it is also a major cause of soil degradation. Soil compaction is a major concern, as it reduces soil porosity and increases the risk of soil erosion and loss of soil organic matter. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to higher compaction risk, with the risk of subsoil compaction now affecting 20% of arable land. This alarming trend calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery, considering intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis is supported by the observation that the largest sauropods had fixed foraging trails. Our findings have implications for the design of modern farm machinery and for the management of soil compaction. They also suggest that the ecological strategies of prehistoric animals may have had a major impact on the evolution of modern ecosystems. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved
